Award.AwardTitle: Particle Hysteresis And Solidification Experiment : Optical and Nucleation Effects (PHASE-ONE)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation supports the research of Professors Giuseppe Petrucci from the University of Vermont and Scot T. Martin from Harvard University who will elucidate the relationships between molecular composition and phase of biogenic secondary aerosols (BSOA) and the subsequent impact on BSOA optical properties and cloud condensation nuclei (CCN) activity. This research will build an unprecedented understanding of the link between molecular-level aerosol properties and the role of BSOA in regulating Earth's radiative balance. The synergism made possible by bringing together established expertise and research infrastructure within each institution would ensure rapid advance of the understanding of this critical aspect of atmospheric organic aerosol.

The improved understanding of the complex interdependent relationships between chemical, phase and optical properties of organic aerosols, as well as the fundamental data that will be obtained will be of great benefit to the atmospheric sciences community at large. Furthermore, the collaborative research and training infrastructure as well as training opportunities, will be enhanced significantly and provide a critical foundation for future advances in this area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aerosols play a central role in the atmosphere by influencing climate, air quality, and human health. Secondary organic aerosols (SOA) are formed in the atmosphere from the oxidation of volatile emissions from plants and are the predominant contributor to the mass of submicron atmospheric aerosols. However, as we continue to probe into the chemical formation of SOA by oxidation of volatile organic compounds, new revelations question our conventional understanding with regard to the chemical, optical and physical properties of the SOA. A major driver for these discoveries is the development of innovative instruments that give us unprecedented analytical access to study atmospheric chemistries and processes. The Petrucci lab has developed two instrumental methods to analyze the chemistry of SOA formation and aging at the molecular level, as well as monitor the particle bounce fraction (BF), which is used as a surrogate of particle phase. The chemistry of particle formation and aging directly impacts particle properties, such as their phase, which can impact the ability of SOA to absorb and scatter solar radiation, as well as their chemical role in the atmosphere as the SOA particles age.

Near Infrared Laser Desorption/Ionization Aerosol Mass Spectrometry (NIR-LDI-AMS) was developed to investigate the chemistry of SOA formation and aging at the molecular level. This innovative instrument samples SOA particles directly into the ionization region of a time-of-flight aerosol mass spectrometer, where the particles are gently vaporized and chemical components ionized with a near-infrared laser pulse. In this way, molecules remain intact, greatly facilitating chemical analysis. This lack of fragmentation permits us to measure directly chemical components in the particles without loss of molecular information. We have used this approach to study not only the oxidative chemistry of known atmospheric precursors to SOA but also to discover new precursors and provide plausible mechanistic pathways for SOA formation. We have integrated this methodology with another innovative instrument developed in our laboratory; in this case, to get information regarding the particle phase (that is, liquid or non-liquid). We are using particle bounce as a surrogate to particle phase. Put simply, harder (less liquid) particles have a greater probability of bouncing when they are accelerated toward a hard surface. By measuring the fraction of particles that bounce, we obtain a direct window into the particle phase.

The PI provides an enriching environment for the professional training of graduate and undergraduate students, as well as post-doctoral associates. He continues to encourage involvement of and actively recruits students from underrepresented groups at the highest levels of research. Presently, the PI’s group comprises 3 graduate students, including one woman who has a direct role in the development, test and use of this novel instrument. The PI’s group also hosts two undergraduates and a high school student that have participated in and contributed to this project. All members of the PI’s group are trained in a number of interdisciplinary areas, including mass spectrometry, gas/aerosol generation and control, and atmospheric chemistry; preparing them for careers in scientific research.
